availability.p: Currently unpublished for TEI Council and editors' use.

sourceDesc.p: This TEI Lite (P4 XML) encoded digital file is the original.

change.item: Reworded discussion of whitespace and rend, now that I'm sure I had it right. Remove references tei.data.string, as Lou's talked me out of it. Changed boolean to truthValue.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: At our meeting in Paris, Council charged the North American Editor with the task to review all current attributes, attempt to classify each as a particular datatype, looking for attributes that need a new datatype, are eligible for requiring a valList, or need extra constraint; also consider use of tei.tokens vs. rng:text, particularly with respect to rend attribute. I undertook this task understanding full well that it was not a small endeavor; however, I did not realize just how monumental an undertaking it would be.

The results of this project should in no way be considered final; quite the opposite, they should be considered preliminary. A first look for guiding further thought. While in many cases the datatypes and restrictions I have chosen are likely be those that TEI ends up using, in others they will not, and in no case should they be presumed definitive at this point.

div.head: Challenges
div.p: We had two essentially conflicting goals going into this project. The first is to reduce the overall number of datatypes used to declare TEI attributes. The second is to provide better validation constraints on attribute values than DTDs could provide.

At our Paris meeting we discussed three mechanisms, in ways quite similar, that might be used to help accomplish both goals at once: to simplify the overall datatype system, but permit tighter constraints on individual attributes. The first was discussed specifically with respect to the extremely common type attribute;A total of 93 distinct attribute/element or attribute/element class pairs. the second was suggested as a generalization of this principle; and the third suggested a slightly more rigorous or formal approach.

The first mechanism suggested was initially expressed in Rationalization of TEI Attributes. It is to declare the type attribute (probably via the tei.typed class) as a datatype then called tei.enumerated, which itself places only one constraint on the value: that it must not contain whitespace. Then, each individual element that is a member of tei.typed declares an override in its elementSpec that changes the attribute definition for type, specifically providing a value list (via a valList element in an ODD file). That value list may be closed or semi. In this system, a closed list consists of only a set of declared values (in which case a user who wants to use a value or values not in the list TEI provides would need to override it in her customization ODD); a semi list is similar, but the resulting RelaxNG would include the open-ended value tei.data.token (in which case a user who actually wants validation of the suggested values would need to remove that entry in her customization ODD). Because it is imagined that members of the tei.enumerated class will always have a restricted set of values in a valList (even if it is of type open and has no members, and thus boils down to tei.data.token, which actually provides no restriction except prohibits whitespace) I have not named this mechanism other than tei.data.enumerated. One way to think of this mechanism is that the schema customizer can almost always obtain her desired effect by changing the valList, not the datatype.

The second mechanism was discussed only briefly and ephemerally; the specifics were never, and may never be, hammered out. It was to permit some method of allowing an attribute to be declared as belonging to a particular datatype, but then to express some further validation information that would override some of the details of the datatype. E.g., an attribute that existed to express a count of some feature (and thus whose value should be restricted to positive whole numbers or zero) could be declared as tei.data.numeric (which permits fractions, negative numbers, percentages, etc.) and then be further restricted to non-negative integers.

Initially I had thought that all uses of this mechanism would be similar to to the example above, in which an additional constraint was expressed. Thus, in my mind, I had been thinking of this as the additional constraint mechanism. But in fact it would be very useful to be able to express loosened constraints using the same mechanism. I.e., if a datatype permits values "a" | "b" | "c", it would be useful to have the capability to declare an attribute as that datatype, but also permitting value "d". Thus it would probably be better to think of this mechanism as additional rules or some such. It should be emphasized that no one with serious technical expertise in the details of the ODD system operations has looked at this mechanism to ascertain whether it can actually be done or not (except when the additional constraint is expressed as a Schematron rule, in which case a separate validation process would be required of the user).

Lastly, it was suggested that a system of datatypes might operate similarly to a class system, and permit proper subclasses. It is not clear to me whether a sub-datatype would inherit the constraints expressed by its parent datatype and then provide additional constraints or permit additional values. At the moment I have no idea of how either such system might be implemented. I have been thinking of this system as proper subclassing.

div.head: Methods
div.p: At the time I began, there were 541 distinct attributes (i.e., attribute/element or attribute/element class pairs). I created a spreadsheet document (AppleWorks 6.0, if anyone cares) that listed each pair along with its declaration as of the P5 stored in CVS on Sun, 15 May 05.

I then went through each individually, checking (and usually recording) what the recommendation had been in previous editorial reports (CDATA attributes in P4 and Rationalization of TEI Attributes), usually reading the current released tagdoc (i.e., version 0.1.2 from Sourceforge) for the attribute, and deciding if it fit into any of the existing datatypes, and if so what additional constraints or laxities needed to be added. I recorded my thoughts in three separate fields: suggested new declaration (generally a datatype), suggested new additional constraints (generally a fragment of RelaxNG or prose describing a Schematron rule), and comments (prose). For reasons I can not explain (and if I could, perhaps would not, for they might be embarrassing) my comments sometimes ended up in the additional field when there was no information in that field. I have corrected some of these, but more may still remain.

div.head: On Tokenization
div.note: Those who are already familiar with RelaxNG and W3C Schema whitespace and tokenization issues can skim this section.
div.p:
Character string values have always been problematic in text formatting systems due to white space issues, SGML worse than most. While XML avoided some of the problems SGML has with whitespace, it inherited others. RelaxNG using W3C Schema datatypes provides several datatypes for handling character strings and their whitespace in different ways.
string
A string of characters, without any whitespace regularization performed. Because XML processors must perform some regularization of white space in an attribute value, using this datatype for attribute values can cause lots of confusion. From Eric van der Vlist's book on RelaxNG: Keep in mind that you shouldn't use the string datatype unless you have a good reason to do so. If whitespace is genuinely significant to your information, use the string type; otherwise, use the token type. Eric van der Vlist, RelaxNG.
token
Whitespace regularization just like the normalize-space() XSLT function is performed: sequences of one or more whitespace characters (U+0009 = tab, U+000A = linefeed, U+000D = carriage return, and U+0020 = space) are replaced by a single U+0020 = space, and the leading and trailing space (if any) are then stripped off. It is important to remember that the value of an attribute of datatype token is not restricted to a single token in the normal computer science sense of the word token; rather the attribute values in both the schema and the instance are whitespace regularized in preparation for tokenization before they are compared to see if the instance matches the requirements of the schema. xsd:string
The same as string, but has one additional (powerful) feature and one (minor) drawback. The additional feature is that further constraints can be applied via facets. This extremely powerful feature allows schema writers to do things like restrict the length of a string or ensure it matches a particular regular expression pattern. The drawback is that your RelaxNG processor has to know about W3C Schema datatypes. This is only a minor drawback because, to my knowledge, all current RelaxNG processors do know about W3C datatypes. xsd:normalizedString
Just like an xsd:string, but tab, linefeed, and carriage return characters are replaced by space characters; but runs of such characters are not reduced to a single space, and leading and trailing spaces are not stripped. I have yet to figure out when this datatype would be useful (perhaps through lack of trying). xsd:token
Just like token, but with the same additional feature and minor drawback as xsd:string.

In addition, there are several datatypes for dealing with strings that consist of only those characters permitted in XML names.
NMTOKEN
As in XML 1.0, a sequence of name characters. NMTOKENS
As in XML 1.0, a whitespace-separated list of NMTOKEN components. NCName
An XML 1.0 name that does not have any colons. QName
An XML 1.0 name, which may optionally have a namespace prefix, but if it does, that prefix must be defined and in scope for the element on which the attribute declared as QName is specified. Name
I haven't figured this one out yet -- the syntax permits colon, but the description in the book says not to use it for names with a namespace prefix.

div.head: On rend being text, string, or token
div.p: Note that there is no difference between declaring an attribute to contain text or string. A processor parsing an XML instance that conforms to a RelaxNG grammar does no more whitespace regularization on the values it hands to an application than those required by the XML specification, regardless of how the attribute is declared in RelaxNG. I.e., the RelaxNG declaration only affects whitespace regularization of the attribute value for purposes of comparison to the schema for validity, not for other processes.

I am currently of the opinion that the global rend attribute should be declared as datatype tei.data.tokens, which corresponds to xsd:token. This means that whitespace regularization would take place prior to validation. Unless users change the declaration to restrict the attribute to a particular set of values, this will have no effect. And if a user particularly wants to retain whitespace when validating against those particular values, she can change the base datatype at the same time she is adding the particular values.

div.head: The Datatypes
div.p: Here is the list of my current recommendations for datatypes for TEI attributes.

row.cell: I.e., a string with no whitespace (ala EDW86)
xsd:date | xsd:gYear | xsd:gMonth | xsd:gDay | xsd:gYearMonth | xsd:gMonthDay | xsd:time | xsd:dateTime | xsd:token { pattern="([01][0-9]|2[0-3]):[0-5][0-9]" }
That last alternate permits times to be expressed as hh:mm, without seconds (xsd:time requires seconds)

That last alternate permits durations like 2yr, 1 year, 3.2 month, 1 wk, +12d, etc. Where there is an SI symbol or a non-SI symbol accepted for use with SI I have used it exclusively; where there is no such symbol I have permitted a variety of possibilities, although (at least for now) the pattern does not permit plurals (e.g. month is valid, but months is not).
That first alternate permits percentages ranging from 0.0% to 100%, with no space before the percent sign.

That last alternate permits percentages of any value with an optional preceding sign, with no space before the percent sign. Note that this declaration does permit scientific notation, as requested on TEI-L recently.
A series of whitespace-separated strings that do not have whitespace themselves.

xsd:language
As mentioned above, I don't know how an additional restriction like this would actually be implemented. If it could not be, the RelaxNG declaration would be xsd:language, and this would be a base datatype.
I am not so sure there is really an advantage to deriving a datatype like this (as opposed to making it a base type) and seek guidance from Council on this issue.
One might well ask why make a datatype that is used only four times and maps directly to a W3C datatype. The answer, I believe, is that it gives us a place to explain how to use this datatype in a manner written for a TEI audience.

Used to constrain the set of values to a possibly open-ended list declared in the ODD files and thus schema. For an open-ended enumeration, tei.data.token is one of (or even the only) value listed, although this would likely be accomplished by an attribute value on the valList in the ODD.
{ pattern = "^#.*" }Used when a constrained vocabulary is declared elsewhere in the same document, e.g. in the handList in the TEI header.
Used when a constrained vocabulary is declared externally, e.g. in a web-accessible XML resource. Otherwise very similar to tei.data.code.
must match the W3C regular expression syntax.

div.p: There are several instances of attributes which I have assigned directly to W3C datatypes, as this seems to make the most sense. For example, the cols attribute of table and cell is just a count, and so I have used xsd:nonNegativeInteger directly. There is, however, one not insignificant argument for creating a tei.data.count datatype that boils down to xsd:nonNegativeInteger: it would give us a place to explain the datatype to TEI users such that they would not have to refer to W3C specifications to find out what xsd:nonNegativeInteger means.

div.head: On tei.data.enumerated, tei.data.code, and tei.data.key
div.p: These three datatypes are similar in nature. In each case, the intent is that the value of an attribute will be constrained to a list of particular values declared elsewhere (although for tei.data.enumerated the valList may be of type semi, in which the resulting list, while providing suggestions, would not provide any actual constraint).Currently, TEI P5 source ODD files are written such that when there is a valList of type semi there is also a datatype specified as rng:text. This should be changed so that the datatype is tei.data.enumerated, and the output of the tangle process depends on the type of the (required) sibling valList. The requirement of the valList could not easily be enforced by TEI RelaxNG schemas, but could easily be enforced by a TEI Schematron rule.
For tei.data.enumerated, elsewhere is in the schema file, and the values are constrained directly by the RelaxNG grammar.

For tei.data.code, elsewhere is somewhere else in the same document instance, and the attribute values are constrained by the RelaxNG grammar only insofar as they must be fragment identifiers (e.g., #hand07), i.e. they must be pointers that do not point outside the current document. However, as with all URI references, the RelaxNG grammar will not check that they actually point anywhere at all. A link-checker must be used separately to ensure this. In many cases, it has not been decided where each attribute should point. I am entertaining the thought that, for those cases where there is not already an obvious place it should point, tei.data.code attributes should point to valItem elements (by pointing to their xml:id attributes, not by matching their ident attributes) that are children of a valList that is itself a child of a specialized element that gives the appropriate semantic.

For tei.data.key, elsewhere is somewhere else, most likely in a web-accessible resource. Here the values are just tei.data.pointers, and a link-checker would need to be used to validate that each points to an available resource.

To summarize: tei.data.code
Possible values (which start with #) are defined by a list that appears inside the current document (most likely in the TEI header). A Schematron rule can validate that a given attribute's value is from the appropriate list. tei.data.enumerated
Possible values are defined by a list which appears in the project ODD customization file and thus schema. TEI provides defaults for when the attributes of interest are not directly addressed by the ODD customization file. In some cases (closed), validation would require that values come from the list of defined values. In other cases (semi), the list provides semantics for the available set of values (and a place to list them for easy reference), but attribute values are not validated against them. tei.data.key
Possible values are simply URI References. They may or may not point to something useful that local software may or may note be able to validate. (Not unlike the P4 key attribute.)

Here is a fanciful example of the use of the resp attribute as tei.data.code. Will Scribbler paleographer Mark D. Errors Proofreader

This is hard to read.

div.head: Application of Datatypes to Attributes: the Details
div.p: The details of which datatype each attribute is assigned to, and what additional constraints or possible values I imagine for them, were imported from the spreadsheet to a MySQL database. With the help of a colleague I have built a simple PHP interface to this database for Council's use. While I am sure there are still errors, it is certainly worth a careful look. Note that NaAA means not an attribute anymore.
